Tis ours in action, but your owne the deede, I must
Shunne all suspition by my presence, looke to't boy.
If thou failest now, for euer loose thy ioy.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.l: Ha, ha, master, I a Welchman, a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: A tricke now on my maiden-head, I did mistrust it, Come leaue the rest to me, this Priest shall marry vs incontinent.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: I, if I were the Welchman.
Because your father gaue him light thereto.
sp.p: Therefore come sirha, weele shift clothes, meete vs at Putney as my father shall mistrust ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Rafe.
sp.l: I will, excusing your departure till anone,

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: do gentle loue.
Heauen on our venture smiles, this to approue.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: O it cannot choose.
Fathers are fortunate in this good newes.
Go ye drones, ye do not loue the hiue,
Theres hony in't, tis a sweet thing to winne.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I must breake the ice for ye, if I slippe vp to the chinne, now you will pull me out, saue mee from drowning mistresse.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Feare it not.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I would bee loath betwixt Welch and English, to bee hanged, mistresse, I cannot liue on the bargaine, come sir, Ile shift with them, and now I must shift with you.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: I clothes, good Tutch.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: And vse me no worse being your man, then I vsed you, being mine.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: O better, better.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.l: O loue, thou art a begger, yet I am thy debter.

div.stage: Enter two sailers with a truncke, wherein is Mistresse Mary in her winding sheete, others with pick-axe and spades, as on the sands.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Set downe the heauiest load
That euer true affection vnderwent,
To you tis like the Anchor of your ship,
Heauy at first, but easly waied seemes light,
To me, that not supports her bodies waight,
Tis heart deep in the burthen, & too ponderous
Sad, heauy is that load, whose leaden poize,
Is as a sullen sorrow, too, too pressing.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Sir, I would wish you to be briefe.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Dig ho this golden beach, whose glittering sands
Shewes with the sunne as Dyamonds set in gold,
Fitly intombs a iewell of much worth,
Whose liuing beauty staind all lapidary.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: She was most gentle which was worth all riches.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: And this nights tempest did a cruell deede,
To take from me a vallue of such price.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Sir, though our seas kill women with their frownes vs their bug-beare threates are womanish, and so we leaue e'm.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Leauing your selfe and all, somtime,

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Euen so, no safer in our beds,
Or on the land, but vnder deaths black stroke,
And he that is the surest, sits in state,
Dyingly tended by the hand of Fate.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: And yet me thinkes death should not
Take her from me, being scarce mine owne.
But newly wed, neuer bedded yet.
So that the Ceremony burning bright,
Himen yet hath his tapers flaming red.
And the bold boastings of that good mans breath.
That all religiously made one of two.
Hardly disgesled in the freezing cold,
Little I thought the priests word being, euer,
Should find his period in so short a time.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Sir, but the gift was giuen ye on condition,
Till death depart, better or worse,
Me thinkes this Catechizing little needes,
To humane guiding, and to you the lesse
Knowing what openly you do confesse.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Beare w'e me maister, he that pines in griefe,
Liues as you sailors doe, thinking at sea,
Euery storme ends, when flattery flouts ye,
So to our loue-sick sorrow comes a calme,
By ease of fancies, when tis furthest,
And many times the weapon that doth wound,
Is salue, and Surgeon both, to make all sound.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Are ye ready sir?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: All fitted, let me take my last farewel,
I am all gelly in my teares and sighes,
Wasted by waiting her vntimely losse,
So long I did consume in drops of woe,
That contrary I laugh to thinke it so.
He that weepes much, hauing no teares to spend,
Smiles out the rest, but inwardly does rend,
O God that I ventring so hard a chaunce,
Should loose my dice, before my hand be out,
Tis euen so, in all things man intends
The losse is ours, the winnings not our friends.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: For charity be breife, should the wind
Turne his beake into the southerne side
Our ship would leaue vs, dally not with griefe,
Once and no more, let sorrow rule as chiefe.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Then thus, and this the last,
Moll, I take leaue yet on thy hersed selfe,
Dead selfe, and selfe slaine. Moll derest
I am thy morning musike, call thee vp,
To wedded rights, I leade thee to the Church,
And there receiue thee, dine with thee at noone,
Daunce all the after day, bring thee at night
Into the wedding chamber, this is it.
And here I leaue thee to thy virgen slumber,
Neuer attempted, as thy birth bestowd,
Madam beginning, take it in thy end,
So liue thus die, onely my married friend,
And nothing else, gone art thou to a power,
Which will with welcomes take thee, left I am
To the worlds crosse, thy father who inrag'd,
Will bitterly reuenge thy death on me,
But I will proue his martyr, se-thee Moll,
Foole that I am to say so, here is all,
Gownes, tire, all abilliments of thine,
No rag shall rest remembrant in my viewe.
To stirre the imbers of thy dying fire,
I kisse thy key cold corse, and with this key,
Lock thee for euer vp, farewell, farewell,
My mouth the Church, my voice thy
Parting knell. All cares that liue and heare
This bell to toule, Christian-like bid peace vnto
her soule.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Amen, be speedy mates, see ye not, looke
The blewnesse of you cloud dos threaten winde,
If it rise faire, we shall be lodgd in France,
But not where please the fates.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: A board, a board, heie.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Hollo, linger no time aboard, you heare
With me ho, will the rest stay? how a yeare?
O God that man should leaue behind,
And liue, the loue of soule and minde.

div.stage: Exeunt, and leaue the pikax and spades behinde. Enter Gouernour and a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gouernour.
sp.l: Sir, welcome to Scillie,
Where I command my brothers friends haue welcome,
But now my flattery gets you on this beach,
Where you prospectiuely see many countries,
Learn this of me, where danger shootes her string,
We in our neighbour neerenesse ought to feare:
But arm'd by our foresight, make bold resist
Aginst the brags of forraigne enemies.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: I haue not seene a better glasse to looke in,
What country call you you, whose cliffes are as the cloudes
smoake, and all shadowing mists?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Sir that is France, a faire beseeming friend,
On yonder continent stands Ireland,
On this side Brittaine, and on that side Garsie,
Ilands besides of much hostillitie,
Which are as sun-shine, sometimes splendious,
Anon disposed to altering frailtie.
We that all neighbor must so strength our being,
As fearelesse we may frolicke yet not seeing.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: I vnderstand ye sir.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Now let my longing haue content in you,
With the report of them you lately saw,
My brother Vergir and his children,
Is he a widower still at More-clacke?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Married sir vnto a London cast a way,
One whose decaied husband left to liue,
(Though poorely) yet your brothers Lady.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: It is his choice, and I subscribd to't,
But for his daughters sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Alas, in them is he vnhappy,
One is haild from him by stolne practises,
The other liues as though she were not his,
A goodly gentle woman, but her owne in heart,
She will be gone to, for her gouernement
Stands vpon will, as men stand on the beach,
Seeing the sea wherein they must be dround,
Yet fearelesse venter on the ruthelesse maine,
She will regardlesse of her father, marry,
And dos as most, long for the miserie,
Signd to them in their cradles.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Sorry am I.
Ha, what scrambled ends heape vp confusedly?
New digd and ript vp is this plot of ground,
Some Shipwrack on my life, hid to deceiue
The Queene and me of our aduantages.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: Likely sir,
And see our sodaine comming scar'd from hence,
In the new ending, such as pil'de this heape,
Behinde them haue they left their implements
Which did the theft, what thinke ye sir if we
Redig the ground, should we depart & leaue it?
At midnight wold they fetch their borrowings.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: I like your purpose, ile make one.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: What doe you thinke it is sir?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: No bodie buried, it is sure some goods,
wrackt on the sea, money or rich commoditie.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.l: Tabacco then.

sp.speaker: Gouernour.
sp.p: Tis likely, for with vs men smoke ther lands thorough their nostrels, shall I tell ye sir, tis a commoditie may well be spared.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: Good lucke a gods name, sir it is a truncke.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Lift sir.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: Tis quicke, it heau'd as I heau'd it.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Yfaith I thinke so to, in heart of hope I will be all so bold, as to breake way.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: Ha.

div.stage: They breake the Truncke open, and she sits vp.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: If you be men and borne of that weake sex,
Which I my selfe professe, being woman,
Pittie the liuing sorrowe of a maide,
Buried for dead, but backe againe recal'd,
By the diuinitie of heauenly power,
Amaze not, I am creature, flesh and blood,
Not as I see me, a pale and earthly Ghost,
The story when you heare it shall make plaine,
The wofull chance of life so lately slaine.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: I had acquaintance with this voice, my cosin.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.l: Tis she, sir, tis Mistris Mary Virger, I know her.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.l: My name recalles my memorie,
And I am such a creature, oh,
My vnckle, where am I? returne againe,
Death thou art wanton in a louers paine.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Cosin I will not question the particulars,
The time calles on a present comfort,
And your life halfe spent,
Makes true necessitie delay no longer,
Therefore come, as leasure we shall heare,
The dying story of your miserie.
How euer, glad I am that such a chance,
Landed in Scilly not in neighboring France.

div.stage: Enter in Filbon in welch attire, and Tutch in seruingmans, like one another, with them S. Rafe, M. Auditor & Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: If euer you vs'd speede, be swift as lightning,
Shoote as the starres in their celestiall sphears,
Go and returne as Paris did from Greece,
With that immatchles Hellen, tell the Priest
It must be done, he will beleeue your haste,
Because twas quickned with the former grant,
And promised by the knight himselfe.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Let me alone to make the way, follow you sonne.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: And if I doe not let me loose my prize.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Wheres the knight?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Busie with one, who comes as coniur'd vp from Cupids quiuer, stroken deepe in loue, he is a Pothecary.

sp.speaker: Tutch
sp.l: I know him his mother was a.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.l: Peace.
sp.p: Him will I busily attend, go you dispatch while I detaine the father, if this proue, tis comicke pleasure in the schoole of loue.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: We must be quick and sodaine, come.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Slip like your Eele.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: If any man know any lawfull cause why these two may not marry, now speake, or else for euer mumb, I am gone y faith.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Master, remember, you ha my tongue.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: yes, and thou mine, let me alone to counterfeit,

div.stage: Enter sir William with Humil, like a Pothecary.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Thinke on your oth.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Sir, if I do not, let me dye.
When I haue poison'd her with this confection:
Be you cloudy kild with sorrow, tis a skin,
Will draw to purpose on the straitest gloue,
But then your promised reward.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: My daughter and my goods,
I haue no other sonne but you, all is thine,
Question not the reason, why this is,
For I haue many, and amongst them one
Sites all the rest, that knowne to thee,
Will rather hasten death, then pitty it.
Go, I will bid my guests, for to this feast:
Shal she haue noble poison, twill cause feare,
Vse lesse suspition, and my mortall hate,
Shall it selfe kennell in the pride of state.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: giue order for the banquet,

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: within there.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, what is your will?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: To murder thee,

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: She dies sir, if I liue, I am a Pothecary.
And can knead the paste to purpose, she is gon
Had she a thousand liues laid vp in one.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Wife, I must haue thee paint,
And set a glosse vpon this louely front,
To moue, and to attract all eies looke as the sonmer,
Which glads all hearts with his bloud-creasing spring:
Vse thy best graces, though most proudly
I will haue it so, fit thee to all state,
Deck't in thy choisest ornament, shine glo-worme,
In the noone of night, for at this supper.
I will haue more then all our friends,
Musike seuerall, Masques and Reuellings.
In which thou shalt be mounted as the bride,
And I the iolly Bridegrome, will tend on thee,
As duty and the time commands me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Whereof comes this cost?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Examine not, but lay your best end now to't
Councell with this Pothecary which I sent for
To the businesse, pray ye vse your art:
For I am bent to this consumption,
Wheres our seruant Iames?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Within sir, shall I call him?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: No, I wil waite on him, for tis my duty.
Such as would spend in feasts, are but the slaues,
To attend the pleasures of consuming knaues.
And I am one of those, he is the flower
That I must crop too in this fatall hower.
Pray ye appoint sir, she will fit you well,
My purse shall puruey what you shall determine,
What we will be wastful sometime, & our owne,
We vncontrol'd may dispose of: tis our loue,
Rather our destinie, hate ioin'd to this brow,
A horne that drawes on death, no matter how.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, in my closset serue your selfe with sugers, there are spices of the purest, vse them in this cost, what else you want, please you command, they shall attend you.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: I want vertue in a mother, are you one?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am a mother to an absent sonne,
But not to vertue wanting, wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Wrong not yourselfe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I neuer will.

div.stage: he discouers himselfe to his mother.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: You haue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Humil, O my shame and not my sonne.
By thee a mother is made miserable.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: By me blacke finne? no by thy owne neglect, made perfect by my true intelligence, and how euer cunning masqu'd and don'd the vissard that so muffled me, I knew not who was in the bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your eies were witnesses.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: And holy ones.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Found you the man you loo'kt for?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: No, twas a subtill straine, so hudwink't truth,
sp.p: I am a traytor if I did not see Iames your man fast in your armes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thou art a traytor then, if any Iames were there, hee was no man of mine, he was thy father.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Maruell not, at leasure I will tell thee all,
His late returne, the tricke to place him here,
My stay, and his continuing in this house, which
Knowne, thou wilt no sin account, to keep our owne.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O you prophetique Fairies, how dally you,
In concaues of our hearts, sham'd at my errour
I thought for euer to be from your sight,
But thinking, truth was blinded, I forethought
Some following businesse, thus I altered
Comming as one disguised to saue her life,
Dam'd for that fact.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: My life?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: You must be poisoned at this feast,
Tis I must do the deede, ô mother,
How are you blest in my returne from trauell,
I that to light bring your offence, so thought,
Must be the pardon at your iudgement brought.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ah me.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: No more, much secrecie calles on vs,
Acquaint me with my father, plead my guilt.
We shall with cunning so vnfold this businesse,
That our hopes shall strengthen as they perish,
No idle practise, but a serious toile,
Must bring home conquest from this long wisht spoile.

div.stage: Enter Henry, Filbon, Tabitha, Sir Rafe, Tutch.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: If I lock vp this treason, let me perish,
No sir, my breast is yet an vncorrupt and holy house,
That harbors in it, nought but honestie, and to do
This wrong to my patron, per deum atque hominem fidem.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: No matter if you tell it now, tis done, finis men
Say, concludes the auncient worke, and this
Though newly done, cries so be it.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: If keepe secrets, can be but offence, and so tis now,
May be, I loose my place, but theres a friend which
Turning calles detraction, at his heeles liues hope,
Whose cunning quicknes euery fault to fauour.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Why true, and we shall as we may excuse it,
Twas a deede done in welch, you vnderstood it not.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: Let me alone to buckler thee sir Henry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Can ye ward your selfe?

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: This was a passe, twas Fencers play, and for the after venny, let me vse my skill.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: How euer girle, thou art my daughter now,
What thou shalt loose in father, from thy owne,
Thou vncontrold shalt find as much in his,
And I am he.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: And I acknowledge both this in my Lord, my head, my husband, at whose bed I am obedient, at whose board I am obedient: all in all, I am the wife of Filbon, whose rough Welch, hath got a constering English, parse it boy, Nounes, Pronounes, Verbs, Aduerbs, and God giue thee ioy.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: With vocatiue ô, your father heares it.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: And ablatiue caret, takes his daughter.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Then in pluraliter, ah has a sonne.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: So singular and plurall all is done.

div.stage: Enter Auditor, like a Merchant still.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: If euer you were swift be nimble now, what haye married, tide this knot?

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: I, and the earnest blow giuen, feare it not.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Sir, I haue set my hand to't, seal'd the deed,
Pray God it cancell not in me.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Then part, and euery one be silent.
There is a feast appointed at the knights.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Our marriage dinner, is it?

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: A gallant one, much cost is threatned. And the good old knight vnbuckles from his backe, the liberall loade of honour, dos proclaime triumphs, and welcome vnto all, calles for his wife, charges her care, commands his seruant Iames to inuite his guests, which in a rolle stands quoted, theres a new come pothecarie, and he bribes, euen grace her selfe in this assembly, and dos promise his furtherance in the businesse, on the sodaine you are mist, daggers and diuels the knight cries wheres my daughter? one vp ascends to search the chambers, another runs to seeke for this lost daughter. I knowing more then much in this her absence, singled my selfe to warne you of his search, hether will hee come, for he feares yong Filbon, missing the suters, calling for the marchant, I answered not (being absent) in this heat: the welch man, where is he? none can be found, cries out he knowes not what, and all his word is now, a plott, a plott, a plott.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: What will ye doe?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Kisse and part, till fit occasion of our next salute, Filbon farewell, my husband thinke on me, I am thy treasure but thou bear'st the keie.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: I will home.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: And I will see the rest, what will you sir doe?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Nay I ha done enough, I am vndone in my selfe, Hei mihi quod nullos, I must doe this deede, twas I pauca the rest, Ile home sir, I.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: What rests for welch sir Robert Morgan, by God was cragge de pen, and the hangman calles to me, da hum a, da hum a?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: I will be at this feast in some disguise.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Ile fit ye sir, tis here, I am tutch right, hic & vbique, euery where.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Now smiles the instant, & wrathes wrinckles seeme,
As smoothed curles vpon a wanton streame,
My hopes grow big, and their diliuery,
Is by our midwife time brought to true birth,
I will not be a pointing stocke tot'h world,
No, if this gossip rumor publish it,
It shall be christned with reuenge and death,
Why when, are we growne sluggards now?
Tardy in bountie, shall we niggard it?

div.stage: Enter Humil in white sleeues and apron, and others posting ouer the stage with boxes.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Be quicke, carry those sweete meats in,
Bid them that in this businesse haue to doe,
That they attend this rich confectionary,
With no common care, the cost commands more loue
And duetie, sir we are fitting to occasion,
Would all your guests were come.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Tis the feasts duetie to attend,
Thou art a willing mischiefe, hast thou fitted
our purpose to the proofe?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Haue I, thinke you I am slack?
Pusht on with hope of beautie and reward,
She dies had she a life more deare.
Then the last spring, sole comfort of the yeare.
But I will couer and prepare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Doe, doe, my daughters thine, my goods, my all,
Blessed beginning to my sorrowes fall.
Wheres my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Here.

div.stage: Enter Lady gallant and braue, while Humil and others prepare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: That one so heauenly faire should earthly be,
Slaue to misfortune, bace in luxurie.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir for to please your eie, I am thus quaint,
Good faith I am asham'd in my selfe.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: How and a woman.
Come blaze thy affections to immodesty,
And tho thy vertues contradict the deede,
Be Venus wanton, smile, with Helens eie,
For I will haue it so.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I was not so brought vp: I shall endeauor, tho my cheekes put on sensuable die of other bashfulnesse.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Sir your honourable guests are come.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nay then you wrong me most of all,
Shew not these signes of feare, all's past,
And I am dead in old remembrance,
Troth I am, forget it, as I doe, say on.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Coches so fill the pauements of your dore,
That scarce can passage giue the footemen way,
Tis not amisse you goe to meete them sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Why well said, spoke with courage, & I wil,
Iouiall like a bridegroome, Lady you see,
They waite on vs, and all attend on thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Worthlesse I am, but since it is your will,
I borrowe light from sun-shine of your beames,
Who glisters so, giues splendor nothing proud,
Dark'ned by feare, halfe hidden in a cloud.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nay hand in hand in faith Iames pardon me,
That dally with the darling of your heart.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Euen so, but little thinking such a thing,
Small gaine springs from that toile, where industry
Sweats in the browes of others victorie.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Father be mindfull, this presuming knight,
Plaies with the flame, burnes in the candle-light,
When we shall furnish to disfurnish him,
Of what he yet enioies.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Humil, tis cunningly contriu'd,
and I attend it.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: For charitie be swift.
Place your plate, and pile your vitriall boales
Nest vpon nest, These for wines and beare,
The other tend the call of altering diet,
Sirrha, quoth he, we shall fit I trow,
The pleasant purpose of loves apppetite,
Ad hand yfaith, and welcome to the feast,
Whose foode is pleasure, dainties but a test,
And I prouide it for ye.

div.stage: Enter Earle, Lords, Ladies so many as may be, S. Wil, and his Ladie in complement.

sp.l: Right noble& my hearts indored friends,
To preach you welcome, were to drowne the sea
With floods of water. Be it knowne vnto ye,
That your comming solemnely inuited,
Hath that attendance appertaining as the Gods
In their selected Baechiuels command,
Mary, the Nectar wants, and the Ambrotia,
Smiles in the presence of such earthly wines,
As the worlds compound furnishes with all,
Though it come shore of lushius surfetting:
Yet willing furtherance makes the value meete
In her best suite of entertaine, sit then,
And let our musicke rellish to the eare:
Such care and cost as loue and welcome giues,
Not to prophane the best except the least,
As prolong to begin this worthlesse feast,

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: Sir we are easily won to fawn on frendship,
Spanniel-like, yet with the smiles of men,
Which redeliuers loue for loue,
What we receiue are treasures safely stor'd,
And shall with interest be repaid againe,
Your free, yet frugall, without lauishing,
Nor come we to make boote of curtesie,
But value kindenesse in her best of loue,
So we dwell in your bountie.
Rent-free welcome.
If you thinke this your receptacle, then
Landlord I am, and shall so soundly proue,
As fines forgiuen, you leese, free borne our loue.
Welcome our tenants Landlady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I do, my duty tenders it,
Sit then and frolicke, for to my hearts liking,
Is this day consecrated, blest the meanes,
That added to it, such prosperitie,
While we sat, sighing on the bancks of bale,
Blisse kist her cheeke, and bids her joy, al haile.
I such a storm as when the shower is past,
It driues destruction to thy soule,
Morral in faith, enigmaies riddles so,
Musike fal too, wife I will seate thee heere.
With pardon of thy betters.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: In yours she is the best& does command
Place and periority i'th vpper hand,
Besides, her beauty merits as the best,
To ouer shine starres, were they here possest,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well mock't my Lord.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: No, not a whit.
My iudgement erres, if otherwise I censure it,
Sit sirs, for I, although inuited, chalenge here
Full flowing welcome, from his lippes that lends,
As vnto me, so much to all my friends,
And I begin vnto ye.

div.stage: The Earle sits, and all do follow him.
div.l: S. Wil. there's a cockrel tight,
That learnes to crow from others, good my Earle,
If that my boldnes may, chalenge thy own,
I promise whose performance lighly giues,
Heart willingnes to boote, cods me fill wine.
div.stage: Filles two glasses, giues her one.
div.l: Skink& carouse, wife charge this common shot
Leauell point blanke, see who thy pearsing eye,
Can marke to hit, if they be bullet free,
They scape the vnder daunt of courtesie.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: They say hees curst that by a cannon dies,
May I be blest in such a destiny
For of all other, I were onely happy,
Being the ey-marke of so faire a shot.
Discharge bright beauty,& shoot home
Make me the man so happy.
I, or me.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Or any, mongst so many, liues free choice
To one as principall, to each a voice.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then to the worthiest, to our selfe my Lord.
By figure of the rest, tis vnderstood,
By the kings nod, he greetes his subiects freely,
Though his eye settle vpon one.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Euen so to me, I answere& acknowledge
Receite of complement bestowed about
On euery willing, and right welcome guest.
Pray ye all memories.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: We do so, and he giues a duty.
To gratulate such seeming courtesie
Nurse, Iohn, vnlook't for better welcome,
This is kindly visitation faith.

div.stage: Enter Filbon,& Tutch, in blew like nurse, and Iohn ith Hospital

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Sir, tis my duty, and my beggard boldnes
Makes me presume to trouble ye,
Knowing how you affect this ignorant,
I brought him to giue welcome to your guests,
Hearing at London of this preparation.
At London, is it got so farre abroad?
You see a niggards bounty how it spreades,
Like to a nine daies wonder gentlemen:
And much the more, because tis seldome seene,
That couetous misers are so plentifull,
Faith, tis much in me.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: We find it so, sir William.

sp.p: now my suck-egge tell me, what's thenewes at London

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.p:
That honest men want, and knaues get money, I ha nothing, nurse has some, dogs are let
loose and the beares vnodone, ha, ha, ha.

sp.l: Came ye by foot Iohn, or by water?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: a horse-backe ith boat.
Art no gal'd with riding Iohn?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: No, but weary with sitting, nurse shall sing a Geneua psalme, and bids these beggars welcome.

sp.l: How beggars, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: All the world is so, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.p: He saies true, chide him not, we are no lesse.
Daughter we come, Nurse all day, at night be your bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: my nurse, indeede my bed-fellow foreuer,
My Filbon welcome, welcome as my husband,
My last, and foreuer best beloued
Iames, To seasons this good meeting,
Take hand in hand with our faire wife and dance,
Gallants, my man can trick it with my Lady,
You shall see else, make not squeamish, to't,
It is my will and what I will shal be.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Beseeke ye sir.
Befoole ye Sir wilt be, wife make not coy

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Since you command it, I am ready.
I trow so, but I trust a potion pleades
By this time to true purpose, dos it not?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I would not be so sped, for all the world
Tis done too late, tis past.
Good ith beginning, let her dance her last
Who fronts me with a Cornu copian wreath,
Were she a wife sprung from the race of kings,
Such bitter breathing followes, now ye lamps,
Of spotted Nemmisis, burne blew, let the fall,
sp.ab:
Light on mischiefes selfe, that dallied lately in our
wretchednes, tel her sad sorrow, tombs and epitafes tend her amazing obsequies,& then liue free thou wrong'd soule from slanders cruelty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am not well Sir, pray ye leaue the daunce.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.l: Not well, Iames be gone.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Sir, you shall pardon me, vnles with her being not well.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Thinke you I will; what leaue my country, sir.
Vpon a slight, a trifle, tis more deare to me.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Wast not thy promise?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Pughe.

sp.speaker: S. William.
sp.l: Pughe.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Madame, leane on me, Ile bring you to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pre-thee daughter, faith I'me passing ill,
Your honour and the rest must beare with vs,
Tis nothing vsuall, a queasie fit.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: The mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No, the husband.
Good faith I am not woman sick, though woman
But earnest ill, clog'd at the very stomacke with
A sodaine calme, I feare me tis my death.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nurse help to bring her to her closset, do.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Excellent fit, supported by vs too.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Plague on't, shall I be left alone, master make haste? But tis my deede, I am author of this shift, hees where hee would be now, Ime where I should be too, but not wel back't, yes now I am.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Besecke ye pardon me.

sp.speaker: Sir William,
sp.l: I am wrongd, and to this company,
I make it knowne by comming of thy daughter:
Is my sonne made her indored husband, shall I
Suffer it, call you this curtesie, tis simple craft?
sp.p: Cloak't vnder thy denial, is this wel to ingraft with vs vnknowne, and so to ioyne yonkers to heirs, he is my onely all, and married vnto thy daughter?

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.l: Ha, Married? Nurse, how is't within?

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Shees very ill sir, and I feare.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: That your disguise is knowne, come iuggle not, call you this Nurse? O thou dissembling boy.

sp.speaker: S. William.
sp.l: Are you married?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sir I must needs confesse it, he's my husband, & the reason?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No matter for the reason, I ha done, God boy ye, Conicatcht by a tricke, and so perswaded, good.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: I am abus'd.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Yes questionlesse you are, I haue all right.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: You haue no wrong sir, I to affirme your word,
When I was woman, and from man I should, and now,
I trust my shape dos challendge but your promise.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I plaid but Iohn come kisse me now saies she, I am Tutch your quondam seruant sir, thrust out to thrust them in, a lawfull marriage is no mockery sir, I counterfeited welch, to ioyne this constring English.

div.stage: Enter Auditor and his sonne Foures.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: What at a gaze sir William? cannot be recald.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No, no, more mischiefe, nay come all together, welcome.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Thanke ye sir.
sp.p: My sonne return'd, surrenders to your doombe his life, for yours so lately lost, deputed in your daughter, for she is dead sir, buried in the ile of Scillie.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Not amisse, whats the next Pagan? all the craft of this is knowne.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Sir had I too hearts to melt this frozen feare, would thaw with passion, the drops distil'd from our tormented braine, witnessed by these sailers that inter'd her, knowes how I parted with her when she dide.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: Is mistris Mary dead?

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: She is.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Well, shall I haue Iustice for her death?

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: Command it sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p:
To prison with him them, for she is murdred, Sir cause you knew your rapine and your theft, tied to your runnaway legs that clog, you were vncertaine of her portion and our loue, therefore to rid that feare, you rid me thus of her (to me) most deare, my owne, my onely eldest of my
daughters, oh.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.l: Ile be his bale.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Sir tell not me of bale, for my assurance pleads in his life, and he shall die.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: You haue no president for that.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Yes, remember Donningtons man, Grimes,
Who for an heire so stolne and married,
Was hanged, and the sergeant at armes
For assisting them, did loose his place,
If this were done, your theft will hardly scape.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: I thought of that indeede.

div.stage: Enter Iames and Humill disguised still.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: Ha, by whom?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: By this faire counterfeit of husband, heres my witnesse, and the deputie in such a mischiefe.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: My wife is made away, poison'd here, and you that should be iust are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: We follow, speake, explaine this mystery.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Your wife sir.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.l: Yes, supposd for dead, as risen from my graue,
I came to More-clacke, but a little late,
Euen when the lying Priest did call her thine,
She knew it, and deuised with her gloue,
To repossesse me of the house she chalengd.
sp.p: so honourd, I slept with my owne, but thought the contrary, you know what happened, that sonne that so betraid his parents thus disguisd, fearing insuing mischiefe, wrought by you to haue poison'd his deare mother, twas your biding, therefore murder, but the will of heauen bad otherwise, and yet she liues, wife what say you?

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.l: That al is so.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: And I affirme it true, my shape cast off dos answere sir in few.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Prettie in faith, no maruell you forswore my bed,
When you had substance for a property,
Sir you must haue your owne, who can deny it?
And I must as the story runs be mum,
Foold in my selfe by my owne slights vndone.
But whats this to my daughter, where is she?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Gouernour.
sp.l: Brother Vergir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Brother George from Scillie, whats the newes?

sp.speaker: Gouernour.
sp.p: That your deare daughter dead and buried sir, by miracle was thus preseru'd, which at more leisure I shall manifest: pray ye forgiue her fault, come theres some wanton blood left yet, saies I, ye will I know, and wrongs past all remedy, the world must vndergo.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.l: My Toures, the dead dos liue, I am thy wife, Mary.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Or her ghoast, a shadowe or a substance.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sister I will teach ye a medecine to make a shadowe substance, ly with him to night, as I will with my Filbon, & by the morning thinke but what is past, and you will reckon rightly you, hele hold you three to one my medicine's true.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Me thinkes I haue a tickling in my blood crosses all anger, malediction hence, hence, thou ill temper'd Feare, this comicall euent seasons the true applause; since welcome is the word, y'faith, I know not what to say, faine I would, & yet a lazy lagging apprehends with doubt, but well I know not what, in me, it lyes to punish or to pardon I wil be generally at, once insooth I will. I am a widdower, gallants, and you meete at marriages, and funerals, so thinke it pray ye, I abridge all complement, barre all opponents, & resolue to fauour you, you, you, and challenge from your lou, perswasion to this purpose, since our fate makes vs the worlds fond Idiot, be it so youth, and your fortune was prodigious to it, and my best of spirit, binds vp in this, all is but thanklesse merit.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: Then Epilogue am I,
Imagine all the world were in your house,
And hearing this report with wondring braine,
I thus excuse it, Gentlemen you see how fortune
Fauours in extremity, if any botcht vp ill, haue
Shew of good, and is not in thee sequell vnderstood,
Yet beare with all, as this old Knight has done,
Loosing a wife redoubled in a sonne, what you shall
Want in iudgement, seeing this, thinke euery
Act is subiect to amisse, so said, so done, will
Bring to true delight, hands meeting thus,
To signe this blessed night.
